metadata.title: Engine Horsepower Calculator – Torque, Trap Speed, and ET Methods
metadata.description: Estimate engine horsepower using torque and RPM, quarter-mile trap speed, or elapsed time and vehicle weight, with methods grounded in NIST- and SAE-referenced formulas.

introduction: Use this engine horsepower calculator to estimate power using three complementary methods: torque and RPM, quarter-mile trap speed, and quarter-mile elapsed time with vehicle weight.

The tool is intended for tuners, engineers, and technically minded drivers who want to cross-check dynamometer results, back-calculate power from drag-strip data, or sanity-check manufacturer power claims.
All estimates assume that measurements are taken carefully, vehicles are in sound mechanical condition, and any track testing is performed safely and legally on a closed course or certified facility.
methodology: The torque and RPM method implements the classical relationship HP = torque(ft·lb) × RPM / 5252, which follows from the definition of one mechanical horsepower as 33,000 ft·lb per minute and the conversion between angular speed in revolutions per minute and radians per second described in standard mechanics texts and engine test documentation.

In practice, torque is usually measured using an engine or chassis dynamometer. The dyno measures torque at the crankshaft or at the driven wheels, then horsepower is computed from torque and RPM using the same equation used in this calculator. Because the formula is dimensionally constrained, it is critical that torque be in ft·lb and engine speed in RPM when you use this method.

For drag racing situations where you have quarter-mile trap speed and total vehicle weight with driver, the calculator applies an empirical relationship commonly used in motorsport engineering: HP ≈ Weight × (TrapSpeed / 234)^3. This formula is derived by fitting power-to-weight data to measured trap speeds for a wide range of vehicles running over 402.3 m (a quarter mile) and is documented in several engineering references and professional calculators.

The elapsed-time method similarly back-calculates horsepower from weight and quarter-mile ET using an empirically calibrated equation of the form ET ≈ 6.29 × (Weight / HP)^(1/3). Rearranging this yields HP ≈ Weight / (ET / 6.29)^3, which is the expression implemented here. Because it depends strongly on launch, traction, gearing, shift strategy, and driver consistency, this method should be treated as a bracketing estimate rather than an exact measurement.

Both drag-strip methods assume that the vehicle is running at or near peak power at the end of the quarter mile, that aerodynamic drag and rolling resistance fall within typical ranges for production and lightly modified cars, and that elevation and weather conditions are not extreme. Serious development work should still rely on laboratory or certified track testing under controlled conditions.

Across all methods, users should treat the results as engineering estimates. For safety-critical or regulatory contexts, such as emissions and compliance testing, follow the procedures and corrections laid out in standards like SAE J1349 for net engine power and consult manufacturer data that is traceable to accredited test facilities.

faqs.question: When should I use the torque and RPM method instead of the drag-strip methods?
faqs.answer: Use the torque and RPM method when you have access to reliable torque data from an engine or chassis dynamometer, or when a test stand provides torque at a known engine speed. It directly reflects the physics definition of horsepower and is the most transparent method when torque is well measured. The drag-strip methods are best when you only have quarter-mile timeslips plus a trustworthy vehicle weight.

faqs.question: Are the horsepower estimates wheel horsepower or crank (engine) horsepower?
faqs.answer: The torque and RPM method will match whatever you feed into it. If your torque comes from an engine dyno at the crankshaft, the result is crank horsepower. If it comes from a chassis dyno measuring at the driven wheels, the result is wheel horsepower. The drag-strip formulas are usually closer to wheel horsepower because they back out the power actually moving the car, but differences in drivetrain loss and converter slip mean the result is still an approximation.

faqs.question: How accurate are the trap speed and elapsed-time horsepower formulas?
faqs.answer: Both quarter-mile formulas are empirical fits to real vehicles and work surprisingly well for typical performance cars in good mechanical condition, often within roughly plus or minus 5 to 10 percent when compared to dyno figures. Accuracy degrades for cars with very poor traction, unusual aerodynamics, power adders used only part of the run, very tall or short gearing, or for runs at high altitude or extreme temperatures where air density differs from the conditions assumed in the original curve fits.

faqs.question: What units should I use for torque, speed, and weight in this calculator?
faqs.answer: The torque and RPM method requires torque in pound-feet and engine speed in revolutions per minute to preserve the constant 5252 in the formula. The drag-strip methods assume vehicle weight in pounds and trap speed in miles per hour, with quarter-mile elapsed time in seconds. If you work in SI units, convert torque from newton-metres to pound-feet and mass from kilograms to pounds before entering values, or convert the resulting horsepower to kilowatts using the provided kW outputs.

faqs.question: Can I use this calculator instead of a certified SAE J1349 engine test?
faqs.answer: No. This calculator is designed for quick engineering estimates, tuning comparisons, and educational use. Certified engine power ratings for regulatory or advertising purposes must follow formal test codes such as SAE J1349 or equivalent standards in ISO-accredited facilities, with tightly controlled temperature, pressure, fuel, and accessory loads. Use the results here to sanity-check data, not to replace official certification.

faqs.question: Is it safe to collect trap speed and elapsed-time data on public roads?
faqs.answer: No. Measuring quarter-mile performance requires high speeds and long stopping distances. It must be done on a dedicated drag strip or closed-course test facility with proper safety equipment, trained staff, and compliance with local regulations. Never attempt to time quarter-mile runs on public roads, and always follow track rules and vehicle inspection requirements.
